Different sub-breeds = different sizes? Or Tecmo oversight?
Monster Rancher Metropolis: Monster Rancher 2 Archive (PSOne): Miscellaneous Q&A (Post New Questions Here): Different sub-breeds = different sizes? Or Tecmo oversight?
By *R* on Thursday, October 12, 2000 - 04:53 pm:

I just noticed in the Elder's Cup that my Gobi (Golem/Henger) was head and shoulders taller than the Sleepyhead (Golem/Baku) in that tourney. So do different sub-breeds scale differently? Or did Tecmo just forget to "age" that Golem to 6 years 3 months old?

*R*

By Dark Phoenix on Thursday, October 12, 2000 - 11:57 pm:

You are not alone. Personally, I think it's the latter. I noticed then same thing with Nostal, the Worm/Zuum.

By Eagle Fierce on Friday, October 13, 2000 - 02:30 am:

Here's a tip for you to try in the lowwer ranks...reset it. For some unknown reason, I clearly remember battling a Milliam with an Angel (starting out), and my Angel was almost twice as tall. I would try to "Bolt" her to death, but hadn't trained much yet, and I would have to reset when I fought the Mana (Sakura Arts). By the third time doign this, I found my Angel was SMALLER than the once tiny Milliam, and the Pixie put up more of a challenge against poor Sierra, as well.

By *R* on Friday, October 13, 2000 - 11:56 am:

I'll give that a try... But if that's the case, then is there no rhyme or reason for their sizes? This could potentially affect combat outcomes, if the life stage of a monster has an effect on its combat abilities, as proposed by a post somewhere on this board (that I don't recall anymore :p). Something about dishing out more damage and receiving less damage during prime, relative to static stats.

*R*

By *R* on Saturday, October 14, 2000 - 01:29 pm:

Well, it's an interesting theory that sounds right, intuitively, but who knows what brand of crack the programmers were on?

If I had a GameShark, I would test it like so:
* 2-player mode, frozen clock for largest test window
* 2 copies of the same monster:
--999 LIF, 999 INT, 999 POW, 999 SKI, 1 SPD, 1 DEF
--100 Loyalty
--0 y 0 m 0 w

I) Use 1 technique with Subject A until subject B is nearly KO'd, repeat with Subject B until Subject A is KO'd, for a total execution of the technique x times, for a sufficiently large x. Record the range of damage, as well as a median and a mean for statistical purposes.

IIa) Age Subject A into the adolescent life stage and repeat I.

IIb) Age Subject B into the adolescent life stage and repeat I. (While Subject A is still aged.)

III) Repeat IIa and IIb for the prime and aging life stages.

This wouldn't cover too many cross-life-stage scenarios, but it would determine if a difference existed between each of the tested life-stages and their adjacent life-stage(s).

But luckily, I don't have a GameShark :)

*R*
